September's been warm and people don't behave as expected when it's warm. That's going to be the theme of the hour, pretty much.

PM11:15am

Something like the second warmest September on record i think

BE

Something like that. Bad for pizza. As, arguably, is Domino's.

11:16 am
BE

Simon French of Cenkos crushes all the news into one paragraph.

BE

n DOMINO’S PIZZA (DOM LN, 373p, £1.8bn, SELL) has announced a robust trading performance for Q3 2016 achieving further progress in system sales metrics, albeit against tough comparatives. The core UK business achieved 3.9% LFL growth in Q3 2016 system sales (c.f. 14.9% in Q3 2015) with YTD LFL sales growth of 8.6%. We believe our full-year 2016 estimate of 10.0% LFL UK system sales growth remains achievable pending a resilient Q4 performance. Digital sales continue to progress, increasing by 18.1% during the period with a continued migration of sales orders being captured online (over 81%) and with 64% placed via mobile/app during YTD. The store opening programme also continues apace with 21 new UK stores opened during the period (51 YTD) with management guidance now being increased from 70 new stores in 2016 to 80. The international businesses performed below our expectations during the quarter with LFL system sales increasing by 7.6% in Ireland and flat in Switzerland, leaving a bigger ask in Q4 trading to hit our full-year expectations. The new Icelandic business has made a positive contribution with 4 stores opened in the year to date while the German JV has performed in-line with management expectations. Despite the tougher H2 trading comparatives, management has today reiterated it remains confident of achieving full-year 2016 results in-line with market expectations (Cenkos estimates – adjusted pre-tax £84.4m, adjusted EPS 13.6p and dividend of 8.17p). The shares trade on a 2016 EV/EBITDA rating of 18.1x falling to 15.1x in 2018 based on forecasts. While the business continues to trade well, there remain ongoing headwinds and there is no room for error in Q4 trading. We continue to prefer the pure-play digital platform JUST EAT, that although trades on a premium (2016 EV/EBITDA of 33.0x falling to 17.9x in 2018), has enjoyed several upgrades to forecasts in the current year and has outperformed the All-Share in contrast to the underperformance observed with Domino’s. In our view this stock offers investors a much stronger profile of reward relative to valuation and we continue to recommend investors switch from Domino’s where the risk to forecasts remains on the downside.

PM11:17am

Always good to cram the news in to one par if you can.

11:17 am
BE

Some debate among the sellside on whether consensus had adjusted down to reflect the weather effect. .

BE

I think the main point here is at 26x 2016 earnings, you don't want to be slowing for whatever reason and on whatever expectation.

BE

Late in the day, Goldman sent a correction to clients. Management had meant only that orders were 5 per cent lower than average on hot days and 5 per cent higher in bad weather, Goldman explained, so a 10 per cent order shortfall would require every day to be sunny this year having been rainy last year.

11:24 am
BE

......... anyway, Jefferies says it's all in the price and what are you worrying about anyway?

PM11:24am

ha

BE

This is David Reynolds, of course.

11:24 am
BE

The UK market much debated, weather-related challenge in Q316, context important here, we think the FY16 guide needs 21% UK order growth in H216. Today's Domino's Q316 print, a useful insight for Just Eat's print 2 November. A clear impact on growth, the tough Q315 comp +14.9% impacting, Q316 +3.9%; logically one would expect a similar dynamic at Just Eat. The JEF model needs +21% for H216 UK order growth to meet the £368m revenue guide; we remain relaxed...

BE

Much debate around Just Eat's upcoming Q316 order update, due Wednesday 2 November. The Domino's Q316 update today, we think is perhaps the most meaningful indicator of how Just Eat will do, particularly in the United Kingdom.
The UK, Just Eat's key market. The home market, one of the most attractive geographies for online takeaway food aggregators and at H116, £111m revenue, +44% YoY growth, 64% Group, driving £58m EBITDA, a 52% margin, +770bps YoY.
The bear perspective. Just Eat being competitively outflanked by the 'last mile' business models and the existential threat continues to grow, will Deliveroo et al leverage a foothold in the casual dining fraternity to launch an assault on the independent takeaway sector, Just Eat's core business customer. The order growth trend in the United Kingdom thus far indicates the challenge, Q116 +40%, Q216 +34% and what next for Q316 +25%?

BE

An alternative, more balanced view perhaps. The timing of Easter makes the actual Q1/Q2 order growth rates c.38% and 36%. The 2015 comps trend thus +50%, +50%, +50% and +44%. Weather something of a tailwind then in '15, it does feel like it was a rather good, and rather extended summer, even in Newport! In recent investor meetings, Just Eat saw consensus Q316 UK order growth expectations at c.+26%, and they appeared relaxed with that. The major rebranding and associated advertising campaign in the second half September, probably too late to drive Q3, but will drive Q4...
Are we too relaxed? 1 March, FY16 guide, revenue £350m, needed c.+29% UK order growth. The most recent H116 guide, 28 July, £368m and H116 UK order growth +37% (Q1 +40%, Q2 +34%) implying c.+21% order growth for H216. Putting it another way, we think Just Eat's H216 ask for UK order growth is c. +21%, the debate currently seems ranged between +25% and +35%...

11:25 am
BE

Domino's Q316 print. For context, Q315 UK LfL sales +14.9% (Q314 +12.9%). 'Trading in our core UK business was particularly robust, more than 75% delivered sales via digital channels, sales were also helped by relatively poor weather during the summer months'. For Q316, UK LfL sales +3.9%, the impact of the tough 2015 comparables clear, 'trading in the core UK business was strong', 'as indicated at our half year results, we are facing some tough comparables in the second half of the year' and on digital '81% of delivered sales YTD have been online'.
And in conclusion. JE's UK business still the mover of the dial. In very good shape and evolving rapidly. The current rebranding key and a clear focus on delivering value-adding technologies to the restaurant network. Q316 could be tough, given the warm weather. Domino's Q316 print this morning indicates that dynamic, LfL growth of +3.9% in the UK versus +14.9% in 2015. The weather tailwind from 2015 making for tough comps and impacting LfL growth rates as a result; one would imagine this dynamic impacts Just Eat too.

BE

And not being glib, but really not sure whether it matters and should it crystallise near-term weakness in the equity, genuinely a time to build/add to positions. Buy, PT 1000p.

11:32 am
BE

Davy incoming to summarise the numbers, so I don't have to.

BE

In the second quarter of the year, total Group sales were GBP172.5m, a (5.4%) decline on the prior year. Trading profit is expected to be slightly lower than the prior year. The Group's profit expectations for the full year remain unchanged due to the careful management of costs (Davy f �132.7m). Grocery branded sales in the quarter were materially lower than expected at (9.5%) owing mainly to the Gravy and Stocks category declining 13% in volume terms while the Desserts category decreased by 9% - both blamed on an unseasonably warm September. Sweet Treats demonstrated accelerating momentum, reporting a sixth consecutive quarter of growth at 6.4%. Sales growth in the second half of FY16/17 is expected to be weighted to the fourth quarter and in the range of 2-4%, dependent on average seasonal temperatures. In the full year, sales are now expected to grow 1-2% and the Group's medium term target of 2-4% sales growth is unchanged. Profit expectations for the full year are unchanged, with this year's consumer marketing costs now expected to be broadly in line with last year's.

BE

Note that it's slightly different from all the previous Premier Foods warnings, though. This one's just sales.

11:33 am
BE

Profit guidance held.

BE

Which is partly on costs. Including, one assumes, marketing.

PM11:01am

You'll have to bear with us for a mo

11:35 am
BE

The group is expected to achieve current market expectations for profitability through a cut in costs, particularly marketing costs, which are now likely to be in-line with the prior year at c£36m rather than the aspired £42-44m; an aspiration set our most recently at an investor visit to Ambrosia in Devon. For choice, we believe this is absolutely the wrong strategic decision. The market can understand up to a point the impact of a hot September in the UK, albeit in Merseyside it was far from cat on a hot tin roof territory, and so a profit shortfall. However, to our minds, Premier would have been much better seeing through its marketing plans and giving grounds to believe that an underlying sales growth rate can be achieved through pre-existing plans rather than doing so with less marketing support. As such, we have to question the robustness of the business’ capability to delivery 2-4% sales growth in the medium-term, an aspiration that has to be depleted as marketing support is materially cut; such tactics within a strategy characterised the stop-go days of Unilever^ (ULVR, Buy at 3742p) in our view.

BE

For us September was demonstrably warm in the UK, the apparel trade is testimony to that, but hardly frazzle country. More to the point, June and July were far from glorious in weather terms, again ask the rag and soft drink trades (Nielsen soft drinks data for July was anaemic after an appalling June). As such the magnitude of the weakness of Premier's Grocery division Q2 and September in particular takes us by surprise, noting as we do secondary data that did highlight some softness in the ambient grocery category. Against a company narrative of a step up in underlying trade from 1-2% to 2-4% in the medium-term post the McCormick shenanigans, this update is clearly unhelpful to the reputation and robustness of Premier Foods’ investment thesis.

BE

One doesn't see phrases like "hardly frazzle country" enough in investment bank research.

11:36 am
BE

Accordingly, following this surprise update we are not changing our consensual PTP expectations for Premier Foods (FY2017, £86.9m; EPS 8.4p), noting the company's overall unchanged guidance for the year. However, noting our concerns about the strategic impact of a slashing of the marketing budget upon medium-term trading momentum for the group’s brands, we have to downgrade our Buy recommendation on the group’s stock to HOLD.

BE

We've talked on here many times, I think, about the Lidl effect on branded consumables.

PM11:37am

We have

11:37 am

BE

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Hidden gem'
Additionally, Sainsbury is also highlighting a boost to the Habitat brand in the UK through the acquisition, with five
units expected to be trading in a supermarket by March 2017. Recently appointed CEO of Sainsbury's Argos, John
Rogers, is reported by the IGD as saying that the Habitat brand is a 'hidden gem', noting a very different shopping
mission compared to Argos. Retail Week report that the Habitat units will be c1400-2000 sq. ft. in size carrying c600
SKUs within Sainsbury stores.
Mr Roger's characterised Habitat shoppers; with three-quarters being female and an over-representation, not
surprisingly, of 25-45 year old ABC1 income bands, so gender aside arguably much more akin to the social profile of
core Sainsbury's shoppers in our view. The London Colney on the north M25, St. Albans and Marshall Lake, Solihull
(West Midlands) Sainsbury stores are reported to be set for a Habitat to open before Christmas 2016 in addition to
Nine Elms.
Mr Roger's is reported by The Guardian as seeing potential for both tens of Habitat's at Sainsbury's and standalone
stores too in time albeit the trial will determine the nature, extent and pace of any roll-out. That said, a sense of
perspective is needed to our minds; it will be the Argos fascia that will determine the success or otherwise of the
Home Retail Group acquisition for Sainsbury's.

I had no idea

Amazon.com Inc. is pushing deeper into the grocery business with plans to introduce convenience stores as well as curbside pickup locations, say people familiar with the matter.

The Seattle company aims to build small brick-and-mortar stores that would sell produce, milk, meats and other perishable items that customers can take home, these people say. Primarily using their mobile phones or, possibly, touch screens around the store, customers could also order peanut butter, cereal and other goods with longer shelf lives for same-day delivery.

11:49 am
BE

GMP incoming.

BE

Genel Energy (GENL LN); SPECULATIVE BUY: £3.50 - DNO (DNO NO) (not covered) announces an operating update in Kurdistan. Plans to engage a third drilling rig were dropped in September due to irregular payments from the KRG. The company expects to re-start investment to boost production at Tawke (Genel WI: 25%) to a targeted level of 135,000 bbl/d following the resumption of regular and predictable payments. Tawke oil production during 3Q16 averaged 109,159 bbl/d (GMPe: 120 mbbl/d). Market reaction: slightly negative on what looks to be a more muted production outlook by DNO. This should not come as a big surprise to investors given the ongoing payment difficulties with the KRG. Genel has in any case a more prudent view on Tawke. The ongoing four well campaign is expected to boost Tawke production to c.120 mbbl/d (+10%) excluding natural decline. This level would be marginally below our forecast of 125 mbbl/d for 4Q16. This probably means that Genel’s FY16 production will be near the lower end of the Company’s guidance of 53-60 mbbl/d.

undefined

BE

PM11:57am

...

11:57 am
BE

Capita’s first profit warning (12-15% EPS cuts in this report), has its roots, we think, in underlying industry returns pressure. Its public sector (c46% sales) activities have been impacted since 2010 by the UK government’s austerity strategy with worsened industry pricing, cashflow and risk transfer terms. This has been compounded by wider UK BPO growth maturation (fewer new tenders, more rebids) and the challenge of rapid technology evolution. Heavy acquisition activity, less conservative discretionary accounting (Trawling the Accounts: Business Services Annual Report and Accounting Review) and sporadically lowered bidding discipline allowed continued EPS growth. But reduced P&L and balance sheet flex meant recent operational slip ups led to outsized EPS rebasing

BE

while the c12% guidance cut relative to FY16 consensus likely includes a degree of padding, we are concerned that underlying returns pressures remain and Capita’s cash conversion of profits is still below sector average. A stretched balance sheet (3.1x FY16E including pension deficit, the highest in Capita’s history) and muted organic growth outlook suggests either the dividend or acquisition activity may need to be curtailed unless the company issues new equity.

BE

1. Absent an equity placing, cancelling the dividend for two years could reduce leverage by c0.5x. This feels a better option than a moratorium on acquisition activity. Bolt-ons are central to Capita’s business model, opening up new markets and refreshing the group’s skillsets and technology. 2. A realistic new medium term margin guidance range of 11-13% (v the current 13%-14%) would imply 8-10% for the group excluding its Asset Services and Software divisions, which enjoy high market shares and barriers to entry. 3. Acknowledging maturation in UK BPO, Capita should continue and intensify its focus on cash generation and, if traction develops, its C. Europe roll-out.

11:58 am
BE

Ed Steele at Citi, of course.

BE

Which gives me licence to note another bit of sellside crossing desks at the moment.

BE

Tony Williams of Hardman & Co has his quarterly UK housing update out.

12:00 pm
PM

Yes! And it's themed.

BE

12:00 pm
BE

Themed to ...... Hang on ....

BE

PM

eh?

12:00 pm
BE

Honestly.

BE

I could explain, but I think the intro explains well enough for itself.

BE

As that interloper, the re-make of ‘The Magnificent Seven’ tanks at our local Odeon, we at Hardman paused to remember The King of Cool, Steve McQueen. And, yes, it was his role as Vin Tanner in the peerless original movie from 1960 that put him on the celluloid map. During filming, too, McQueen constantly (and very effectively) showboated so as to upstage the leading man at that time, Yul Brynner. Steve went on to become the World’s highest paid movie star in the early 1970s.

12:01 pm
BE

Wait for it ........

BE

But he kept his friends and Robert Vaughn, who’s still hanging in there, was a life- long chum of McQueen and co-starred with him in both ‘The Magnificent Seven’ and ‘Bullitt’; and is in possession of a prize anecdote.
At the height of Steve’s stardom, he hosted a hip Hollywood party at his ocean front house in California. Out on the deck, Vaughn said to McQueen: “did you ever think it would turn out like this?” McQueen looked at him blankly and replied: “who said it was going to turn out like this?”

BE

........... not yet .... keep going ...........

12:01 pm
BE

Steve was street savvy, but he was not the smartest knife in the drawer, which makes his Delphic comment to Robert Vaughn all the more surprising.
What Steve was saying is that “it’s not over yet”; that there is still a lot more to come (sadly for McQueen, who died in 1980 aged 50, it was a future that was not his).

BE

............ Any minute now ......

BE

The same is true of Brexit and the collateral undulations that it has riven in the UK Housebuilding Sector.

12:02 pm
BE

YES!

PM

BE

Isn't it! Should I skip to the conclusion?

12:02 pm

BE

This is page 24.

BE

12:02 pm
PM

hahaha

BE

There is an argument somewhere in here. Really there is.

BE

Near term, we believe there is greater latitude for bad news than good (for which apologies) and the Mayor of London’s proposed inquiry into the impact of foreign investment in the Capital’s housing market has also set the cat amongst the already ruffled pigeons. At the same time, the Government is taking away i.e. the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme will close at the end of this year. But it is also giving with a new £5 billion allocation to speed up building on public land and to offer loans to smaller developers. Don’t hold your breath on the latter though and, nearer term, with the current beneficent dividend flows from the housebuilders, we suggest treating their shares like bonds until the broad sunny uplit lands emerge once more.

12:03 pm
BE

There it is. Make what you will of the rest.
